title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #226: Entire Functions Preserving Rationality**

Is there an entire non-linear function f such that for all x ∈ ℝ:

x is rational ↔ f(x) is rational?

**Answer:** YES (Barth-Schneider, 1970)

More strongly: For ANY two countable dense sets A, B ⊂ ℝ, a transcendental entire function mapping A to B exists.
mathContext: A beautiful problem at the intersection of complex analysis and number theory, solved by constructing transcendental entire functions with precise arithmetic properties.

title: Entire Function
content:
**IsEntire:**

A function f : ℂ → ℂ is entire if it is holomorphic (complex differentiable) on all of ℂ.

**Type:** Differentiable ℂ f

Examples: polynomials, exp, sin, cos. Counter-examples: 1/z (pole at 0), sqrt (branch point).
mathContext: Entire functions are the 'nicest' complex functions - they have power series expansions valid on all of ℂ.

title: Transcendental Entire Function
content:
**IsTranscendental:**

An entire function is transcendental if it is NOT a polynomial.

Examples: e^z, sin(z), cos(z). These have infinitely many zeros, while polynomials have finitely many.
mathContext: Transcendental entire functions are 'more complicated' than polynomials - they have essential singularities at infinity.

title: Countable Dense Set
content:
**IsCountableDense:**

A set S ⊂ ℝ is countable dense if:
1. S is countable (can be enumerated)
2. S is dense (every interval contains points of S)

**Examples:** ℚ (rationals), algebraic numbers, {m/2^n : m,n ∈ ℤ}.

title: Rationals are Countable Dense
content:
**rationals_countable_dense:**

ℚ is the canonical example of a countable dense subset of ℝ.

**Proof:** Countability follows from ℚ ≅ ℤ × ℤ⁺. Density follows from Archimedean property.

title: The Erdős Question
content:
**ErdosQuestion:**

Does there exist an entire non-linear function f : ℂ → ℂ such that for all x ∈ ℝ:

x ∈ ℚ ↔ f(x) ∈ ℚ?

The function must preserve rationality in both directions: rationals map to rationals, and ONLY rationals map to rationals.
mathContext: This is the original question posed by Erdős, appearing as Problem 2.31 in Hayman's 1974 collection.

title: The General Question
content:
**GeneralQuestion:**

For ANY two countable dense sets A, B ⊆ ℝ, does there exist an entire function f such that f(A) = B?

This is the natural generalization: can we map any countable dense set to any other?

title: Barth-Schneider Theorem (1970)
content:
**barth_schneider_1970:**

For any countable dense sets A, B ⊂ ℝ, there exists a transcendental entire function f such that:

f(z) ∈ B ↔ z ∈ A (when restricted to ℝ)

This powerful result says we can map ANY countable dense set to ANY other while staying within the class of entire functions.
mathContext: Published in 'Entire functions mapping countable dense subsets of the reals onto each other monotonically', J. London Math. Soc. (1970).

title: Monotonicity on ℝ
content:
**barth_schneider_monotone:**

The Barth-Schneider construction can produce a function that is strictly monotone on ℝ.

This is remarkable: a transcendental entire function can be monotone on the real line while mapping countable dense sets to each other.

title: Answer: YES
content:
**erdos_question_affirmative:**

The answer to Erdős's question is YES.

**Proof:** Apply Barth-Schneider with A = B = ℚ. The resulting function:
1. Is entire (holomorphic on ℂ)
2. Is non-linear (in fact transcendental)
3. Preserves rationality: x ∈ ℚ ↔ f(x) ∈ ℚ

title: General Question: YES
content:
**general_question_affirmative:**

The general question is also answered YES.

For ANY two countable dense sets A, B, the Barth-Schneider theorem provides an entire function mapping A to B.

title: Complex Extension (1971)
content:
**barth_schneider_complex:**

Barth and Schneider extended their result to ℂ in 1971.

For countable dense A, B ⊆ ℂ, there exists a transcendental entire f with f(A) = B.

This is even stronger: we can work in the full complex plane.
mathContext: Published in 'Entire functions mapping arbitrary countable dense sets and their complements onto each other', J. London Math. Soc. (1971/72).

title: Weierstrass Products
content:
**Key Technique: Weierstrass Products**

The construction uses Weierstrass products to build entire functions with prescribed zeros.

Given a sequence of zeros {a_n}, we can build an entire function with exactly those zeros using infinite products.
mathContext: Weierstrass showed every entire function can be factored in terms of its zeros.

title: No Polynomial Works
content:
**no_polynomial_works:**

No polynomial (of degree > 1) can preserve rationality.

**Intuition:** A polynomial of degree n takes each value at most n times. But there are infinitely many rationals mapping to infinitely many rationals - this forces transcendence.
mathContext: This uses algebraic number theory: if p(x) is rational for all rational x, then p must have special form.

title: Erdős Problem #226: SOLVED
content:
**erdos_226:**

Complete solution: YES, there exists an entire non-linear function preserving rationality.

The function is necessarily transcendental and can be made monotone on ℝ.

title: Complete Summary
content:
**erdos_226_summary:**

1. **Original Question:** ∃ entire non-linear f with x ∈ ℚ ↔ f(x) ∈ ℚ? → YES
2. **General Question:** ∃ entire f with f(A) = B for countable dense A, B? → YES
3. **Transcendence:** The function must be transcendental
4. **Monotonicity:** Can be made strictly monotone on ℝ
5. **Extension:** Works for countable dense subsets of ℂ too
